definition: to take an official post/to become a government employee

to do/to make/to produce/to write/to compose/to act as/to engage in/to hold (a party)/to be/to become/to function (in some capacity)/to serve as/to be used for/to form (a bond or relationship)/to pretend/to feign/to act a part/to put on appearance

sentences.english: But Mr Shu says surprises like the one for Ms Zhang are good tests of bureaucratic talent.
sentences.chinese: 但小张认为这种测试是选拔做官人才的良好方式。

sentences.english: Even if after the commoners serve as an official, still receives the hereditary scholar class the discrimination.
sentences.chinese: 庶族即使做官以后，依然受到士族的歧视。

sentences.english: His farther should thank Huan for his efforts in financing family members.
sentences.chinese: 缓做官赚钱资助家人，做父亲的是应该心存感激之心。

sentences.english: The provincial imperial examination is held once every three years and those who pass it will be appointed as officials.
sentences.chinese: 乡试每三年举办一次，通过乡试的人就可以做官了。

sentences.english: Look at this "chief of everything" phase as your chance to learn.
sentences.chinese: 把“首席什么都做官”这个阶段当作学习的机会。

sentences.english: He did not bother about amall matters in personal behaviour and in being an official.
sentences.chinese: 他为人和做官都不拘小节，讲求实效。

definition: to take up an official post
graduate/successful candidate in the imperial provincial examination
an official position/a job in the bureaucracy
to secure a position/to take an official appointment
successful candidate in the highest imperial civil service examination/palace graduate
